feed.title: Whatever, Dood!
feed.subtitle: I *think* this is a pretty typical blog...

entry.title: Oh my - a Google Phone Interview
entry.content:
I have a phone interview scheduled with Google in two days time. I'm a *tad* stressed out. As in I don't think I'll sleep very well until it's over. I've Google'd (heh) for information on how Google conducts interviews and so far it sounds like it'll be tough. I have a bad feeling the interview will focus on:
  1. CS concepts and algorithms that I studied in school but never had to apply in real life;
  2. Brain teasers (I'm not very good at those);
  3. Um, other hard stuff :)
Scary.

link.title: Oh my - a Google Phone Interview

entry.title: Any questions?
entry.content:
I recently received an email from a colleague:
"The server is on my desk. I believe I mentioned the to [name removed] yesterday over I'm.

I will regarding rack it once we identify rhe 1850 the shoild have been unracked.

Ups 5 is at 100 percent. We can not regarding rack this server until the other 1850 is powered off and pulled.

Any questions should be directed to me."
I have a question: um - what?

entry.title: Rising cost of health care: up 25 - 33% in one year?!?
entry.content:
I'm a self-employed IT contractor with a non-group health care insurance plan, so I make a monthly payment to the insurance company to cover my entire family (there are five of us). My current deductible is over $3,000, meaning the insurance company doesn't chip in on doctors visits until I've paid more than $3K, and that's YTD dollars. So my deductible payment balance starts over at $0 on 1 January. So far my monthly payment has been a little over $400/mo. which is manageable, and we didn't have to make too many deductible payments last year.

And then I got a letter from the insurance company. It seems the "rising cost of health care" is going to cost me an extra $200 per month, or I can increase my deductible to over $4,000 . So it looks like the cost of health care in the USA has increased by something like 25 - 33% in the last year.

WTF? Wouldn't an increase like this be news? Or is this unique to my insurance company? Am I being screwed? If so, I didn't even get dinner and drinks...

link.title: Rising cost of health care: up 25 - 33% in one year?!?

entry.title: Can I get a side order of hollow-points with that please?
entry.content:
It had been a while since the family had had some good old fashioned IHOP for dinner so we decided to treat ourselves the other night.

By chance we're seated at a booth near the entrance and it turns out we have a good view of folks as they enter and exit. When a couple of guys left the restaurant my wife and I noticed that one of them was wearing a shoulder holster containing a semi-automatic pistol. We figured he was a police officer since we've heard they must carry a weapon at all times. We didn't think much more about it until we left IHOP.

As we're loading the kids in the van, the armed gentleman leaves the restaurant with his companion and what appears to be their families: they've got young ladies with them and small children, one of which is an infant. They proceed to load up the car next to use with the kids and I notice that one of the young ladies is wearing a hip holster containing what looked like a pearl-handled 45-caliber colt. She's wearing a tight tank-top, low-cut jeans, and A PISTOL. As we pulled out we left the armed couple chatting and sharing a cigarette.

I wonder why they carry guns. Maybe they both were officers. Maybe they think they're safer from terror attacks if they carry pistols.

Whatever, dood!

link.title: Can I get a side order of hollow-points with that please?

entry.title: Unusual morning commute
entry.content:
I normally wouldn't bother mentioning my morning commute except that this morning's was definitely out of the ordinary. This is what I saw:
  1. A policeman had a pulled-over driver out of their car and hand-cuffed. He seemed to be interrogating the guy. I'm a suburbanite so I hardly ever see this.
  2. A little further down the road a box-van was pulled-over and emergency personel were working on the driver who was still in his seat and looked unconscious.
  3. I passed an extremely slow driver (like 25 mph in a 55) who looked like he was shouting at himself and everyone else on the road.
Might as well add this: and now we're having unbelievably stormy weather this afternoon. We're under a tornado warning, meaning tornadoes have been spotted in the area.

Hrm.

entry.title: JSTL Date Formatting is Locale/Language Sensitive
entry.content:
Ever write a JSP that contained JSTL-formatted dates? Ever found that the formatted date appears differently when requested via a text client like wget?

I recently built a web page that uses JSTL to format dates using the pattern "dd MMM, HH:mm:ss". In a browser this renders as: "04 Nov, 13:03:00". However, I found that when I requested the page using wget, the dates were formatted like so: "2006-11-03 13:03:00.0". I found a post at sourceforge that suggested setting the locale for JSTL in the page itself. I didn't want to have to modify the JSP so after some trial and error found that sending the header "Accept-Language: en" in the wget request fixed the problem. *sigh*

It's little frustrations like this that build up and make me (and others I bet too) want to look for other solutions and/or frameworks. GRRR!!!

link.title: JSTL Date Formatting is Locale/Language Sensitive

entry.title: Ugh - mouse crud
entry.content:
What the heck do I call this crud that accumulates on the feet of my mouse? It looks like it's a combination of dust, lint, and secret sauce in a tacky layer that makes the mouse drag instead of glide across my desk. Sometimes I can scratch it off with my fingernails, other times I have to use my car keys or something hard and sharp.

I think I'll call it "MOUD," short for "MOuse mUD."

What-EVER.

entry.title: Zero-left-padding with java.text.ChoiceFormat
entry.content:
Sheesh.

After a cursory search, I couldn't find any examples of how to format new Integer(7) as "007" in Java. So I snooped around the java.text package JavaDocs and got this test to pass:

-snip-
import java.text.ChoiceFormat;

import junit.framework.TestCase;

public class RemoteAddressToInetAddressUnit extends TestCase
{
public void testDotNotationStringToBigNumberThingy()
{
ChoiceFormat formatter = new ChoiceFormat("0#00|9<0|99<");

String[] splitAddress = "127.0.0.1".split("\\.");

StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder("");

for (int i = 0; i < splitAddress.length; i++)
{
sb.append(formatter.format(Integer.parseInt(splitAddress[i])));
sb.append(splitAddress[i]);
}

assertEquals("127000000001", sb.toString());
}
}
-snip-

It seems like there should be an easier way to do this, and I'm sure there is. But there it is.

Grrr.

entry.title: Reflecting on the Immigrant Day of Action Thingy
entry.content:
The May Day immigrant day of action definitely affected me personally:
  1. I had no trash service that day (yuck);
  2. Traffic to and from work was *very* light, which was actually nice for a change;
  3. I noticed a different crew/team of folks that normally clean and stock the kitchens/bathrooms at the office building.
It's interesting to think about that list: one could say that immigrants "do the jobs that most Americans don't want to do," like trash removal. One could also argue that an unmanaged immigrant population places excessive stress upon the infrastructure (traffic levels). I don't know what 3 means, except maybe the landlord company gave some folks the day off.

I live in northern Virginia (USA) and while I see immigrants everywhere, I did not expect to be affected personally. I was definitely surprised.

link.title: Reflecting on the Immigrant Day of Action Thingy

entry.title: My Question of Faith
entry.content:
I don't really have a good reason for not doing what probably 90% of the worlds population does: believe in a God (or Gods).

I've read that personal tragedies can make a person loose their faith, such as the death of a child, loosing your home to a natural disaster, or contracting a horrible disease. I have friends that burned out on God as a child in a heavily religious household. I also know people that found God later in life and are happier now than ever. I haven't suffered any tragedy, my parents weren't all that religious, and I don't think I'll come to believe in God later in life.

However, I feel like I'm unusually lucky, I would say blessed (if I believed that). I have a wonderful wife and three beautiful children. We're all healthy and fit. I have a job that I enjoy. We're paying off our house and state education contracts early. Many folks in my position Thank God for this.

So why don't I?

entry.title: I couldn't wait to share this...
entry.content:
I recently had a funny email conversation with my system administrator the other day. I've reproduced the conversation here, removed names and proprietary info, etc. In our defense, it was early in the morning and both of us were busy and bit punchy:

- begin -
System Administrator (SA): I think there's something wrong with gate4. I checked the queue and it hangs when it checks data on 4. Is there a way to check the queue depth on the gate itself? Records in the database for today so far is a little over 300,000, which is about half of what it should be.

Me: If you can access the web-console on gate 4 then you can drill down the JMX tree to those components. What's the jboss-server.log saying on gate 4?

SA: I see the following over and over:
20060119 012937 WARN [TP-Processor25415] Unexpected error processing request: "System overload: Maximum number of concurrent requests (100) exceeded" [Source IP: ...

Me: Can you send me the last 1000 log entries from that file please?

SA: There. [A log file was attached to this email.]

Me: It's empty.

SA: You know why I can't check it from the app box?

Me: I give up, why?

SA: I don't know, that's why I'm asking you. You think I should restart jboss on gate4?

Me: Oh - I thought you were setting up a joke. :-/ Can you ssh into gate4? If so, can you get me the last 1000 lines from the jboss-server log? [Notice I ask for the same data again b/c my earlier response that the emailed file was empty went into the bit bucket.] Don't bounce it - I'd take the Apache instance on gate 4 down. Leave JBoss up so we can diagnose, k?

SA: Hmmm... too early in the morning for a joke. Anyway I gave you the log file.

Me: Yes, but it was empty. [*sigh*]
- end-

SA ended up sending me the log data I asked for, but then someone else told him to bounce JBoss so we lost the sick patient.

We ended up not doing any research into the root cause of the JBoss crash. It's just a beta, dood!

link.title: I couldn't wait to share this...

entry.title: Hi my name's JavaScript and I like to eat poo.
entry.content:
Is it common knowledge that JS engines in FF (and IE?) transform hypenated CSS attribute names into "camelCaps"? I.e. background-color is manipulable in script as element.style.backgroundColor. Grrr.

Thanks to whomever had this discussion on IRC: http://www.irclogs.ws/freenode/javascript/17Oct2005/2.html

Coming up next: a funny email conversation I had with a client sys-admin.

link.title: Hi my name's JavaScript and I like to eat poo.

entry.title: More DHTML + Ajax
entry.content:
I'm definitely a convert now. And not because of the hype factor. Here's why I prefer building browser applications in an "Ajaxian" architecture over traditional MVC/Model-2:
  1. Better separation between View/UI components and Model/Business services. You really don't need to be a Java developer to build and maintain the View/UI. I think that J2EE role purists would appreciate this.
  2. HTML and JavaScript are the language of the client platform. It's common sense to consider those languages for a browser-based View/UI.
  3. Simplified components across the board.
  4. High traffic sites and service providers have helped to bring the browser shops together and produce a de-facto standard for browser scripting languages so the risk of browser compatibility is reduced.
I've only built one Ajaxian application so my opinion might change (duh) but for now there it is.

entry.title: Mental Drivers
entry.content:
So I'm driving to visit family for the holidays and I saw what may be historys dumbest two drivers on the road.

If you're familiar with the "mixing bowl" I-95 interchange in northern Virginia, you know that it's a somewhat intimidating mess of ramps, merges, commuters, inter-state travelers, and construction. Here's what it will look like when it's done:


So anyways I've just merged onto I-95 and there's a mini-van in the lane to my left, just in front of me. A sedan in an on-merge ramp to my right has just merged into my lane and is neck and neck with the van. Both vehicles begin to brake in what at first appears to be a contest to see who can be the nicest driver. It looked like they wanted to trade lanes as my lane was bearing right to go around the belt-way and the lane the van is in is heading for I-395 and D.C.

After a few seconds of braking both vehicles come to a stop.

Yes, they both actually stop in the middle of this mess on a busy travel weekend. Traffic immediately begins to pile up in my rear view mirror because two of the five lanes are now blocked. I find a space to pass on the right and do so, rubber-necking to see what's going on. Perhaps someone is hurt, angry, whatever.

Turns out both drivers have their windows down and are having a friendly conversation.

What-EVER, doods.

entry.title: DHTML and Ajax
entry.content:
So I've been playing a little with DHTML and Ajax for a spike/prototype of a web application. I must say that so far I've really enjoyed building an interactive web app like this. It sure beats all the mechanical tedium of traditional MVC/Model-2 J2EE web apps.

I wonder if I can make this blog more interactive and dynamic...

entry.title: What the heck happened to Spongebob?
entry.content:
Has anyone else noticed that Spongebob seems different this season? His voice, the animation style, the audio quality, just about everything seems different. Not to mention the funny's all gone too. I'm very disappointed. It all seemed to change when Nickelodeon made the movie.

This is something I'd blog about because I watch a lot of Nick -- having three children under 7 means I watch a ton of Nickelodeon and Noggin.

Whatever.

link.title: What the heck happened to Spongebob?

entry.title: Hi my name's Apache and I like to eat poo.
entry.content:
Why is Apache such a pain to use on XP? I'm no 1337 h4X0r or anything, but for crying out loud Apache is sensitive.

So's PHP for that matter.

Grrr.

link.title: Hi my name's Apache and I like to eat poo.

entry.title: Job Satisfaction
entry.content:
Okay, so I didn't start with background, upbringing, etc.

I'm very happy about work. The system I helped build for my client has been operational for a couple of weeks and seems to be working just fine. It's really gratifying to see the fruits of one's labor, even if we did just duplicate the functionality of Dave Winer's old service. The icing on the cake was finding out that the blog hosting service I'm using to host this weblog integrates with our new system (Settings -> Publishing -> Notify Weblogs.com). Sweet.

entry.title: First post!
entry.content:
So I figured I might as well start maintaining a blog about, well, me. I hope this doesn't mean I'm extra-vain. Whatever, dood.

I guess I'll start with my background, upbringing, etc, move on to school, sports, college, work, family, etc. You know, stuff that's only interesting to people named "No One."

Cheers,
WD
